sp.p: Pray Sir will you pleaſe to look upon it, and then acquaint the Court with ſome of the Contents.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: N •• th, You are ſure, Mr▪ Bowes, that Mr. Jenniſon was in Town in Auguſt▪

sp.speaker: Mr. Bowes,
sp.p: He came then from Tunbridge.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: That is all, we can make no more of it: Did he meet you at Windſor?

sp.speaker: Mr. B • wes,
sp.p: No my Lord, I was gone to Windſor before, and when he came I was gone out of the Town.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What time went you to Windſor?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bowes,
sp.p: The twelfth or thirteenth of Auguſt; it was on a monday or a tueſday after I came from Tunbridge.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer,
sp.p: Then we ſhall call one witneſs more, and we ſhall prove by him▪ that is one Mr. Burnet, that the 17th of Auguſt he did meet Mr. Jenniſon going to Winddſor. Pray call Mr. Burnet.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Pray Sir do you know Mr▪ Jenniſon?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burnet,
sp.p: I met him as I was coming from Windſor, that day Dotchets Horſe Race was.

sp.speaker: I. C. J.
sp.p: What day was that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burnet,
sp.p: I cannot exactly remember the day,

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What month was it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burnet,
sp.p: In Auguſt.

sp.speaker: I. C. J.
sp.p: Was it the middle of Auguſt, or the latter end?

sp.speaker: Mr. Burnet,
sp.p: It was about the middle of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: • . C. J.
sp.p:
This does not ſo • uch relate to you, but it is to give ſatisfaction to all the world, that what was aſſerted by Mr Ireland all along, and at his death, and ſeems to be juſtified by ſo many witneſſes as were produced on that account, to prove that he was not here in Auguſt, is utterly •• true; for this Gentleman Mr. Jenniſon ſwears he ſaw him here in Town the 19th of Auguſt, and to prove that Mr. Jenniſon was here,
here is Mr. Bowes and this other Gentleman that come to fortifie his Teſtimony, who ſwears preciſely, tha • the 19th of Auguſt he was at Mr. Irelands Chamber, where he ſaw him pluck off his Boots, and talk'd as if he came Poſt then from Staffordſhire.

sp.speaker: Corker,
sp.p: I ſuppoſe it will not be permitted us to make any argument upon this neither as yet.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer,
sp.p: But now Gentlemen it will behove you to take Notes, for we ſhall come home to you, and we begin with Dr. Oates.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ward,
sp.p: Pray Sir, will you tell your whole knowledge of this matter, and apply your ſelf as near as you can to every one of the Priſoners at the Bar.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p:
My Lord, in the month of July Mr. Aſhby came to Town ſick, and being ſick, and one of the Society, the Priſoner at the Bar, Sir George Wakeman was his Phyſician, and being his Phyſician he did write him ſome Inſtructions how he ſhould order himſelf before he went, and at the Bath; That he ſhould in the firſt place take a pint of milk in the morning, and a pint of milk at night, and ſhould drink no morning draughts but milk, and that he ſhould have one hundred ſtroaks at the Bath at the Pump, I do not ſo well underſtand what that means, but I ſuppoſe the Court doth, but▪ theſe were the words of the Inſtructions. In this letter Sir George Wakeman did write, that the Queen would aſſiſt him to poyſon the King, and this letter was brought by a meſſenger to maſter Aſhby. Within a day or two after I ſaw Mr. Aſhby and Sir George Wakeman the Priſoner at the Bar (he was ſo called) but I had no acquaintance with him, but juſt the ſight of him) I ſaw him ſit in a writing poſture, I ſaw him lay by his pen, riſe up and go away, and the ſame hand that he left behind him in a paper where the ink was not dry, was the ſame hand that writ the letter to mr. Aſhby. And▪ my Lord, in that time of converſe while he was writing, this mr. Aſhhy did give him ſome inſtructions concerning the Commiſſion he had received of being Phyſician to the Army. Now▪ my Lord, in ſome few days after there came a Gentleman for ſome of the Fathers from Wild •
houſe, that had the Title either of Sir Richard or Sir Robert, but he was a middle-ſtatured man, and a brisk man, about the age of four of five and forty, and be came with Commands from the Queen for the Fathers to wait upon Her at Somerſet houſe and I did wait upon theſe Fathers, there was Father Har • ourt, Father Kaines, Father Longworth and Father Fenwick, and another Father, I cannot remember his Name. And may it pleaſe your Lordſhip, we did attend at Somerſet- houſe, and the Fathers went in to the Queen into a Chamber where ſhe was, and I waited in an Anti-chamber, and I did hear a Woman • voice which did ſay, that ſhe would aſſiſt them in the propagation of the Catholick Religion with her Eſtate, and that ſhe would not endure theſe Violations of her Bed any longer, and that ſhe would aſſiſt Sir Geo. Wakeman in the poiſoning of the King. Now, my Lord, when they came out, I deſired that I might ſee the Queen, and ſo when I came in I had, as I believe, from her a gracious ſmile. Now if it pleaſe your Lordſhip, while that I was within I heard the ſame voice ſpeak thus to Father Harcourt, and asked him, whether he had received the laſt 1000l. and it was the ſame Tongue, as l can poſſibly gueſs, the ſame voice which I heard when I was without, and I ſaw no other Woman there but the • ueen, and there were theſe Fathers. My Lord in that very month of July Sir Geo. Wakeman was propoſed 10 • 00l. in the preſence of Father Harcourt, and Father Fenwick I think was there, and Father Ireland.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you there?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates
sp.p: I was there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was this propoſal made to Sir George Wakeman after this diſcourſe you heard at Somerſet- houſe?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, I will not be poſitive whether it was before or after, but it was near that time, this 10000l. he did refuſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you ſay, you heard the 10000l. was proffered him; pray who did propoſe it to him?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Aſhby, was to do it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But who did it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates
sp.p: It was Aſhby in the name of the Provincial, from whom he had received inſtructions ſo to do.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you ſay in your hearing 10000l. was offered him by Aſhby.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord,

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What ſaid he?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: He refuſed it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What words did he uſe?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: He ſaid it was too little.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What was the 10000l. to be given for?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: To poiſon the King.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were thoſe the words?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, they were.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How did the diſcourſe begin?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates
sp.p: I will tell your Lordſhip how: There was a Meeting of the Fathers for this very purpoſe to treat with Sir George Wakeman before Aſhby went to the Bath, & there being a meeting they did break this buſineſs to him; but what preamble they made to it I cannot remember. My Lord, as for the other Priſoners at the Bar, Mr. Corker—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But before you go from this matter, you ſay you know not how they brought it in, but they brought it in ſome way, he was to meet with them to that purpoſe, and there Aſhby did tell him he ſhould have 10000 l. What Anſwer made he to it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: He ſaid it was too little for ſo great a work.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates
sp.p: That is all that I remember.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he ſay what he would have?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I can't remember that, but he ſaid that was too little.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. J.
sp.p: Did he ſay he would have five more, or any other Sum?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: No, that was not then mentioned; but there were Letters preſently diſpatched to Whitebread to tell him, that Sir George Wakeman had refuſed the 10000l. and then this ſame Whitebread did order the Fathers in London to propoſe five more, which propoſal was made to Sir George Wakeman. This I ſpeak but by hear ſay, and it was accepted, and 5000l. of it received in part, and Sir George Wakeman's Name was ſubſcribed to the Entry-Book.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ſee his name ſubſcribed?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: To the Entry-Book.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was that Book kept?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: It was the Book that the Jeſuits kept: it was then in our cuſtody.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Whoſe cuſtody?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: The Father Cuſtody:

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Whoſe particularly? And at whoſe Chamber was it kept?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: At Wild-houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro. Sowyer.
sp.p: Do you know who was the keeper of it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I cannot poſitively ſay that, I ſuppoſe the Secretary and the Fathers.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro. Sawyer.
sp.p: And what did you ſee writ in that Book?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: That ſuch a day (which day I cannot remember) but ſuch a day in Auguſt ſo much was propoſed to Sir G. W. and he accepted it, and received it: thoſe were the words, or to that purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Were thoſe the words writ in the Book?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, or to that purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Do you know whoſe hand writ that?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I can tell whoſe hand, it was Father Harcourt writ thoſe words▪

sp.speaker: L. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Sir George Wakeman's hand was not to it, was it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, it was juſt underneath: Received ſo much money of Father Harcourt by the order of Edward Coleman: now there was the Goldſmiths Name to it, I cannot undertake to ſay who it was, but in my conſcience I think it was St • ley.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſtice.
sp.p: How much was the money?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates
sp.p: Five Thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was Sir George Wakeman's hand ſubſcribed to that Receipt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes it was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Once more; what were the words in the Book?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Memorandum. Such a day 15000l. was propoſed to Sir George Wakeman which he accepted. I tell you the purport, and the words as near as I can.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was it ſaid for what the money was propoſed?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I will not be poſitive in that, I ſuppoſe it was.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: But you ſay it was written ſuch a day 15000l. was propoſed to Sir George Wakeman. and by him accepted?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, and then underneath it the Receipt was written, and this Receipt was written thus, Received in part of this 15000l. 5000l. of Father Harcourt by order of Ed: Coleman. George Wakeman.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was the Receipt, which is ſaid ſuch a day, the ſame day that the other?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: There was no other date to it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Had the firſt a date to it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, it had.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What day was it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: It was in Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Corker,
sp.p: What day in Auguſt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Corker,
sp.p: About what time in Auguſt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: It might be betwixt the beginning and the middle.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But we will ſuppoſe for the preſent queſtion a • ay; ſuppoſe it was written the 10th of Auguſt, There was propoſed 15 • 00l to Sir G. W. and by him accepted, & then comes afterwards this note, Received then 5000l in part of this 15000l with his Name to it. Was there any other Date to that?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: No, that was ſet down as the ſame day, Received 5000l in part by the Order of Edward Col man.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And then Sir George Wakeman's Name was ſet to it at length, was it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Sir George Wakeman,
sp.p: Where was that Received? In whoſe chamber?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I cannot ſay that.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was there any place mentioned in the Note where it ſhould be Received?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: No, my Lord; I was then ſick of the Stone, and was not at the payment of the money.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But did the Note mention any Name? Received of any body?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: It was by Order of Mr. Edward Coleman, 5000 l in part of this 15000 l

sp.speaker: Sir George Wakeman,
sp.p: Does he ſay this was in the Entry Book?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman,
sp.p: Where was that kept?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Sometimes at Wild houſe, ſometimes Mr. Langhorn had he cuſtody of it.

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman.
sp.p: I humbly beg of the Court that mr. Staley may be ſent for.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He only ſayes he believes mr: Staley paid it.

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman,
sp.p: Does he me • tion no place where it was Received?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman,
sp.p: No • no perſon it was paid to?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, he ſays, A • l I ſaw is this, that in the Entry Book ſomeimes kept at Wild-houſe, ſometime by Mr. Langhorn, the • e was w •• tten, This day (which was ſome day in Auguſt) propoſed to Sir G. W. 15000l, and by him accepted, and under that a line or two more which contained, Then Received, 5000l by order of Edward Coleman, being part of this 15000l. George Wakeman.

sp.speaker: Sir George Wakeman,
sp.p: Will your Lordſhip pleaſe to give me leave to ſpeak ſomething now, I may forget it hereafter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ward,
sp.p: We have not done yet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Sir George, they have not yet done with this Witneſs for the King.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: North, Take a memorandum of it in your paper.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Sawyer,
sp.p: Pray what do you know more of the priſoner at the Bar, Sir G • orge Wakeman?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: This is all I can recollect at preſent.

sp.speaker: S • r R. Sawyer,
sp.p: Do you know any thing of any Commiſſion that he had?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I did urge that he received a Commiſſion to be Phyſician-General of the Army.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ſee that Commiſſion?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, I ſaw it in Sir George Wakeman's hands.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Had you ſeen it before?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, I had.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where did you ſee it in his hand?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: When he was writing at Mr. Aſhbys.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Note was that he left behind him there?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: It was an Apothecaries Bill, as I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What month was it that you ſaw the Commiſſion?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: It was in July,

sp.speaker: Mr. Ward,
sp.p: What do you know of his being privy to the Conſult in April?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I cannot ſpeak any thing to that.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Did he write his name to that Bill?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I cannot ſay that▪ my Lord, it was finiſhed, but I cannot be poſitive about the Name:

sp.speaker: L, C. J.
sp.p: But you ſay, that you believe that the Name of Goerge Wakeman. was the ſame hand wi • h that you ſaw when he writ the Apothecaries Bill?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p:
It was as near as I can gueſs the ſame with that letter that was writ to Aſhby▪
wherein he does direct him to take a pint of milk in the Morning, and a pint of milk
〈◊〉 the Evening and that he ſhould have 100. ſtroaks at the Bath: And this hand was the ſa • e with that of the Apot • ecaries Bill.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You never ſaw Sir George-Wakeman write in you life, did you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I ſaw him in a writing poſture, and I ſaw him lay by the Pen.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you did not ſee him write?

sp.speaker: Dr Oates.
sp.p: No my Lord, But the Gentleman that ſat by him was lame of both his hands, and c • uld not write: And I ſaw him lay by the pen, and when he was gone away the Ink was not day.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: You ſpeak of that only to ſhew the likeneſs of the hand.

sp.speaker: Sir George Wakeman.
sp.p: Have you not ſaid that you do not know my hand?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I have told the Court be • o • e how far I have known your hand. I ſaw a Letter that I ſ • y was ſigned and ſubcribed George Wakeman, and that was the ſame hand that was to the Receipt, and to the Apothecaries Bi • l.

sp.speaker: Sir George VVakeman.
sp.p: Have you not ſaid poſitive • y that you do not know it, and is not that matter on Record?

sp.speaker: D • Oates,
sp.p: I did ſee a Le •• er ſubſcribed George Wakeman, 'tis a fine gentile hand, and after I ſaw him in a writing poſtu •• , I ſaw him ſay by the pen, the ink and paper was wet; I did not indeed ſee him write, but there was no body in the room that could write, or in a writing poſture but h • , for the other Gentleman was lame of both hands.

sp.speaker: Sir George Wakeman.
sp.p: But I pray give a poſitive Anſwer to what I ask you; have you not ſaid you do not know my hand?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I do not remember I have ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: But he ſayes now he believes that the hand that writ the letter to Aſhby and the Bill that he ſaw green, when no body was by that could write but you, were the ſame.

sp.speaker: Sir George Wakeman,
sp.p: Have not you ſaid before the King and Council, that you never ſaw me in all your life, and that you did not know me?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, you may be pleaſed to know, when I ſaw Sir G, Wakeman at the Council, I had been up two nights together, and the King was willing once to excuſe me from ſtaying any further Examination, and being ſo ill and indispoſed for want of reſt, in reſpect both of my Intellectuals, and every thing elſe, I might not charge him ſo home, but now I have a proper light whereby I may ſee a mans face, I can ſay more to him.

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman,
sp.p: This is juſt Coleman's caſe, the light was in your e • es.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: This is the ſame Gentleman: I deſire he may propoſe his Queſtions to the Court.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: This is his Queſtion, whether you did ſay before the King & Council you did not know Sir George Wakeman?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I do not remember whether I did or did not. I ſaw one called Sir George Wakeman, and this is that man; but I will not ſay this was the man that was before the Council when I was there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. P • mberton,
sp.p: Did you ſee the Commiſſion in this mans hand?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you know this Gentleman before he wa • at the Council?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oater
sp.p: I ſaw this Gentleman with Mr. Aſhby, and he can't deny it.

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman
sp.p: Can't deny it! Yes I hope you will be able to prove it, You ſaid you never ſaw me in your life before you ſaw • e at the Counc •• .

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did you ever ſee him more than once?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, twice in Mr. Aſhby's Chamber.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What two ſeveral dayes?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates
sp.p: Yes, two ſeveral dayes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton.
sp.p: Where was it that you ſaw him when the writing you ſay was green that he left bhind him?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: It was at Mr. Aſhby's Chamber.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You never ſaw him before that, did you?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: No.]

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How often after?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: But once after that.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was that at the Council?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
Look you what he ſayes, he never ſaw you but twice before he ſaw you a •
the Council.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I ſaw you when the 10000l was propoſed to you.

sp.speaker: Sir G. VVakeman.
sp.p: Where was that?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: At Wild-houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir George VVakeman.
sp.p: Did mr. Aſhby lie there.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: He did lye there, becauſe the Provincial was beyond Sea, and he came up to London in order to go to the Bath.

sp.speaker: Sir George VVakeman.
sp.p: What day was that propoſal made to me?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: It was before Mr. Aſhby went to the Bath.

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman,
sp.p: In what month?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: In the month of July.

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman.
sp.p: By whom? By Mr. Aſhby?

sp.speaker: Dr, Oates,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir G. VVakeman.
sp.p: In the preſence of whom?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Father Harcourt, Father Ireland, and Father Fenwick.

sp.speaker: Sir G. VVakeman.
sp.p: You will be ſure to name thoſe that can be neither Witneſſes for me nor againſt me.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Who can help that?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: I reckon up ſuch as you did keep company with.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know when mr. Aſhby went to the Bath?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: The latter end of July or beginning of Auguſt, as I remember. And this was before he went, he ſtayed but fourteen or ſixteen days, as I remember, in Town.

sp.speaker: L C. J
sp.p: He ſays he ſaw you but twice, once when you writ that Note, and the ſecond time when the propoſal was made to you.

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman,
sp.p: And you knew all theſe things at that time when I was examined before the King and Council, turn this way and anſwer me.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oat • s.
sp.p: I am not bound to anſwer that Queſtion.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you muſt anſwer his queſtions if they be lawful.

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman,
sp.p: I ſay I ask him, whether he knew all theſe things before that time I was examined before the King and Council.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: That muſt needs be, for all theſe things were done before.

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman,
sp.p: Then I ask him this Queſtion, why did you ſay before the King & Cou • ci • , that you knew nothing of me but concerning one letter that was writ from Mr. Aſhby to mr. Fenwick? ſhall prove this upon you; but, my Lord, let me obſerve this, can any one believe that if ſuch Evidence had been given in to the King and Council againſt me as he now ſpeaks of, that I ſhould not have been immediately taken into Cuſtody. but that I ſhould have my liberty ſo long as I had?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: I will tell you, Sir George, you will do very well and properly to call up your witneſſes by and by when you com to make your defence, and to prove what he ſaid at the Council-Table. Pray Dr Oates, what was the reaſon you did not give the ſame Evidence then you do now?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p:
I c • n by and by give an anſwer to it, when it is proved by him what I did ſay. • s to 〈◊〉
Corke • I ſay this, he had a patent from the ſee of Rome to be Biſhop of London; and Mr. Corker was privy and conſented to a propoſal that was made by
Langhorn to the Benedictine Monks, whereof he is one. And theſe Benedictine Monks did contribute 6000 l. to the Society of the Jeſuits in order to the carrying on of this Deſign. And mr Corker, though he did deny before ſome Juſtices of the Peace, that he did go out of the Kingdom, yet he did go over to Lampſpring in Germany, and ſtaid there ſome ſhort time, and he did write a letter; but whether it was dated from Lampſpring in Germany or no I cannot tell, becauſe there was only the date of the month, but not of the place from whence it came, but the latter end of Auguſt it was, a • d therein he wrote, that he did conſent to the propoſal for the raiſing of the ſaid 6000 l. for he is Preſident of the Benedictine Monk • , and therefore it was neceſſary that he ſhould give the Suffrage, and he had been with • ather L • Cheſe and the Engliſh Monks in Paris, and had given an account what proſpect of Affairs he had in England, and how the Deſign went on.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was this in a letter?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: To whom was that letter directed?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: It was directed either to Father H •• cheot, or to Father Howard then in. London.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſaw the letter?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: Yes, I ſaw the letter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you acquainted with his Hand-writing?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I will ſhew you how far I might be acquainted with his Hand: my Lord, this Gentleman, as I think, went away in July, as near as I can remember, I won't be poſitive in the time he went over, but in the month of June I ſaw this Gentleman with mr. Fenwick, and he had given him an account either of ſome Friend or Kinſman of his at St. Omers▪ that had not his Penſion paid, and mr. Corker did give a Note under his Hand to mr. Fenwick where to take up ſo much money, and the money was to be received of mr. Langhorn.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How much was that money?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: It was about 20 〈◊〉 25 l. and he ſubſcribed his Name to it, James Corkers for that is his Name, though he is indicted I know not how by the Name of Anthony: and I have a Summons to give Evidence againſt Anthony Corker.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Juſt.
sp.p: He is Indicted by the Name of James.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: And then I ſaw his Name to an Examination that was taken by Sir Charles Harbord, and ſome other Juſtices that were of the Houſe of Commons that took the Examination of this Corker, and it was the very ſame Hand he uſually writ, only it was not ſo fair, nor ſo well in his Examination. This is that I ſay againſt Mr. Corker.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer,
sp.p: Shew him that Hand there: pray, Sir, look, upon it. (Then a paper was ſhewn to him.)

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates.
sp.p: This is the ſame Hand.

sp.speaker: Corker,
sp.p: Is that a Copy of my Examination before the Juſtices?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It is the Original.

sp.speaker: Corker,
sp.p: I am glad it is there.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Shew it the Priſoner.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: Mr. Corker did uſe to beſtow the Queens Charity—

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Is that your Hand?

sp.speaker: Corker,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Shew him the other.

sp.speaker: Corker,
sp.p: Theſe are both my Hand as far as I can ſee.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p:
That Note he gave to Fenwick for the receiving this money was the ſame Hand with this, and ſo was the letter that came, as we ſuppoſe, from Lampſpring in
Germany; but I cannot ſay it did ſo, wherein he did give conſent to the raiſing and giving this 6000 l. for the carrying on of the Deſign.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer,
sp.p: What was that you had more recollected?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: He did diſpoſe of the Queens Charity (as it was ſo called) but mr. Corker did ſay it was to carry on the Deſign; and this he did ſay in the month of June, when he was with mr. Fenwick. Now what he meant by that Deſign, I leave to the Ju • y to judge, only ſome parcels he had diſtributed two or three ſhillings to ſome, and forty ſhillings to another, to ſome more, to others leſs: but a great part of it he did uſe for the carrying on of this Deſign, and he ſaid the Queen had given him Orde • s ſo to do.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob▪ Sawyer,
sp.p: What do you know of his being privy to the Conſult of the 24th of April?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: He did know of it, and I will tell your Lordſhip how I know he knew of it. He did except againſt Pickering being choſen.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: To do what?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: To do that wicked thing to kill the King, for ſaid he, Pickering is commonly attendant upon the Altar, and he thought it not ſo convenient that he ſhould be employed about that buſineſs, becauſe he might miſs an opportunity by being▪ at High Maſ, whereas another, a Lay-man migh • do it.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer,
sp.p: Were you preſent when the exception was made?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p:
Yes, it was when the Order was given about the money to
• enwick▪

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: At whoſe houſe was it?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: At the Benedictine Convent in the Savoy.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer,
sp.p: Was it expreſſed at that time what Pickering was to do?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: His being privy to the Conſult in April, I had it only from his own mo • th, for he wondered that the Jeſuits ſhould employ Pickering in that buſineſs, when they might have a Lay-man who was more fit; he being a Religious man and attending upon the Altar, it was not ſo convenient.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was that 6000 l. to be raiſed?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Out of the Benedictinct Eſtates.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was he their Preſident?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, he was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Elly •
sp.p: Dr. Oates, was he againſt the thing, the doing of it at all, or againſt Pickerings doing of it only?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: He was only againſt Pickerings doing of it.▪ He would have had a Layman employed in it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Juſt. Pemberton,
sp.p: That is plain, for he did give conſent that the 6000 l. ſhould be raiſed for the carrying on the whole deſign.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer,
sp.p: Do you know any thing beſides that letter you have mentioned, which he writ, to give his conſent?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Nothing, b • t that becauſe he had given his Conſent the mony was paid.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know it was afterward; paid?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I believe that the money was paid, for our Fathers ſaid that they had received it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder,
sp.p: What ſay you to the reſt of the Priſoners?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p:
Mr. Marſhal I do charge with the ſame, that is, that he was act • ally preſent at the Benedictine Convent when the 6000 l. was agreed to be cont • ibuted, but
it was not to be paid till they had an Anſwer from Mr. Corker.

sp.speaker: Sir. Rob. Sawyer,
sp.p: That Letter you ſpeak of was an Anſwer to it I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes my Lord, it was ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer,
sp.p: What do you know of the Conſult, was he privy to that?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I will not be poſitive as to mr. Marſhals being privy to the Conſult, I know that he was privy to Pickerings undertaking to kill the King.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer,
sp.p: How do you know that?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Becauſe he was of Corkers Opinion that they had better take a Lay-man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder,
sp.p: What ſay you to Rumley?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: He is a Benedictine Monk, or at leaſt-wiſe a Lay-brother. And he was privy to this Conſult in which the 6000 l. was agreed to be paid and given, and I do judge he did conſent to it, for he did pray God that it might have good ſucceſs, and that the Catholick Cauſe might once again flouriſh in England.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: He was there then, was he not?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes he was there, but only as a Servant, a Lay-brother of that Order.

sp.speaker: L. C. J North,
sp.p: Why, is he profeſſed?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: Yes, I think he is.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: What time was this, Mr. Oats?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: In Auguſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North,
sp.p: Was it the former part of Auguſt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I cannot be poſitive, but I think it was.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer,
sp.p: Can you ſay any thing more againſt the reſt of the Priſoners?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I do not recollect any thing more at preſent,

sp.speaker: Mr. Ward,
sp.p: Now Gentlemen, if you pleaſe to ask him any Queſtions you may.

sp.speaker: Rumley,
sp.p: Were you there preſent?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: Rumley,
sp.p: Was it in the month of Auguſt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer,
sp.p: Will any of you ask him any more Queſtions?

sp.speaker: Corker,
sp.p: He ſays I went in June to Lampſpring, now I would ask Mr. Oates where Lampſpring is?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: We ſuppoſe it to be in Germany.

sp.speaker: Corker,
sp.p:
'Tis almoſt at the furtheſt end of Weſtphalia, and he ſays that being there, I had o ••• ourſe with le Che • ſe and the Engliſh Monks at Paris about this deſign, I would
• ain make ſenſe of this if I could.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: To ſatisfie Mr. Corker, I cannot ſay that he went to Lampſpring, but only as he ſaid himſelf, and they uſed to ſay they go to one place when they go to another: as Ireland ſaid he went to St Omers, when he went into Staff • rdſhire.

sp.speaker: Corker,
sp.p: Where and when did I give my Conſent to the deſign about murthering of the King, for you named the 24th of April.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: This is that I ſay to the Court, that the privity that Mr. Corker, had of the Conſult of the 24th of April was that I had out of his own mouth, in which he did declare, that he did think the Jeſuits had not done well to make choice of one of their Order to do that buſineſs ſince he was to attend upon the Altar, but it would have been well if they had made choice of ſome other Lay-man to match Grove.

sp.speaker: Corker,
sp.p: You tell me I had a Patent to be Biſhop of London.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I ſaw it in your own hand.

sp.speaker: Corker,
sp.p: Who gave me that Patent?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I did not enquire into that▪

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Did you hear me ſay, I accepted of it, and ſhould be Biſhop of London.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p:
I heard you ſay this, you hoped it would not be long e're you ſhould
exerciſe your Epiſcopal Function.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I now recollect ſomething more. I remember Mr. Marſhal was preſent when Father Hitchcot and Father Howard and Conyers the Benedictine Mo • k, were there preſent about the laying of a Wager, whether or no the King ſhould eat any more Chriſtmas Pies, and this Benedictine Monk Conyers did la • he ſhould not, and another Gentleman lay'd that he would, and this Gentleman Maſhal did go halves with Conyers that he would not.

sp.speaker: Marſhal,
sp.p: I deſire you would tell my Lords the Judges how long you have known me, and where you have ſeen me?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I have ſeen this Gentleman ſeveral times, but had never any familiarity with him, but I have ſeen him • fficiate at the Altar.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: How long have you known me.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: Firſt and laſt two years▪ but the firſt time that I knew you to hear you ſpeak, was when Father Hitchcot and the reſt were there.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: he ſays, he hath known me this two years, and yet never ſpake to me.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: I knew him by ſight.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: He looked upon me as a Prieſt it ſeems, he knew me to be engaged in this buſine • as he ſays, I wonder he ſhould never converſe with me.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: There are a great many that I know by ſight, whom I never did converſe with.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you infer from that? It may be you know ſome of the Ben • h by ſight that you never ſpake to before nor they to you.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: what day of the month was this Conſult? Dr. O • t • , It was in Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Marſh • ll,
sp.p: But what day of Auguſt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: 'Tis a great priviledge that I tell you the month. It was between the firſt and the middle of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He tells you it was the former part, but it lies in his breaſt whether he will or no to tell you exact the day.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: My Lord, 'tis impoſſible to make a defence, if Circumſtances of time and place be not mentioned.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis fit he ſhould anſwer if he can tell the time, but if he cannot we can't help it.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: But if he does not name the very day he may name the place.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He does name the place, it was at the Benedictine Convent.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: Why can't he as well remember the day?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: If they will tell me when the Feaſt of the Aſſumption is, which is a Feaſt of their making, then I will give them a pretty near account when it was.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: The Feaſt of the aſſumption is the 15th of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: My Lord, it was either the day before or the day after.

sp.speaker: Marſhal,
sp.p: Now he hath avouched this poſitively.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: Nay, I will not be poſitive.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: But you were • o, that it was the day before or the day after.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I appeal to the Judges of the Cou • t.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: If he will ſay it let him, but people are not to be ſnapt up thus. Mr. Oats, you are • pon your Oath, and pray anſwer the queſtion that is asked by the Priſoner as poſitively as you can. If you can, ſay ſo, if you cannot, ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: My Lord, I do believe verily it was either the day before or the day after.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Are you ſure it was?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: My Lord, I do verily believe it▪

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: But what accuſation is it of a Thief or a Murderer upon the high-way unleſs you tell the time exactly?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You ſee he will not anſwer poſitively.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: Mr. Oats, was I at any other Conſult beſides this one?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: Yes, you were upon the 21th day of Auguſt, if it fell upon a Wedneſday.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: What matter is it what day it fell on?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: If it were a Wedneſday, then the 21th of Auguſt you were at a Conſult when we had Letters from Arch-biſhop Talbot, wherein we had an account of the State of Ireland, how the Iriſh Affairs did ſtand, but it did not pay an Ir • ſh Letters price, and therefore I ſuppoſe it came from this ſide of the Water, though it was directed as if it came from Dublin. And this was read there, and there was in it a Prayer that a Commiſſion might be ſent down, and there were ſome Jeſuits, and ſome Benedictines, amongſt whom Marſhall was one, and he did give his Conſent that the Commiſſion ſhould be ſent down.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Commiſſions were they?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: For Officers in the Army that was to be raiſed there.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: Where was that letter read?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: At the Benedictine Convent.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: And this you ſay was the 21th of Auguſt.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And that was on a Wedneſday as the A • manack ſay.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: There he agreed to ſend the Commiſſions into Ireland for the appointing of Officers, and did conſent to the poyſoning of the Duke of Orm • nd.

sp.speaker: Rumley,
sp.p: When was Picke • ing taken?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: He was taken the • ight before, or Micha •• mas day in the morning.

sp.speaker: Rumley,
sp.p: Were not you there, Mr. Oats?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: Yes, I was.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Were you at all the Conſults?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: No, I was ſick when Sir George Wakeman was offered the 15000 l. and receiv'd the five.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Conſults were you at?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: I will anſwer to thoſe Conſults that theſe perſons are affected in, there was one Conſult about the beginning or middle of Auguſt, there was another the 21th of Auguſt, and then there was another Conſult wherein the 5000 l. was paid or ordered to be paid to Wakeman, and I was not there.

sp.speaker: Rumley,
sp.p: Who was the meſſenger that took Pickering?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
sp.p: I do not know him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J
sp.p: Was the Conſult of Sir George Wakeman after the 21th. of Auguſt?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: No my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ward,
sp.p: Will you ask him any more queſtions?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oats,
sp.p: My Lord, I deſire I may have leave to re • i • e, becauſe I am not well.

sp.speaker: L. C. J
sp.p: You muſt ſtay Dr. Oats, till after their defence 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Mr. 〈◊〉
sp.p: If you deſire to have any refreſhment you ſhall have it got for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer▪
sp.p:
Then we call Mr. Bedlo •
next (who ſtood up) Pray Sir, ſpeak your knowledge concerning the Priſoners at the Bar.

sp.speaker: Mr. 〈◊〉 .
sp.p:
My Lord▪ before I ſpeak any thing to the Priſoners, I deſire there may be a difference between the Clerks of the Council and me decided, they have miſtak • n
a word in my Evidence, and put in New-Market for VVindſon.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What does that ſignifie to the preſent buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: I deſire it may not be brought againſt me in my Evidence.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then 'tis only for a Caution before hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: The latter part of the laſt Summer, it was I think about the beginning of Auguſt Sir George Wakeman was at Harcourt's Chamber, I my ſelf was there firſt, and when he came in he fetch'd a turn or two about the Room ſeeming angry and diſcontented, and asked Harcourt if he had any thing for him. Then Harcourt asked him how he did proceed? ſaid he, I don't know whether I ſhall or no; for what reaſon am I d • ill'd on in ſuch a Concern as this? Says Mr. Harcourt, ſtay Sir George you need not be ſo haſly to bla •• e us, for we are better provided for you than you think for. VVith that Harcourt went to his Cabinet and took out five or ſix Papers, and brought a ſmall Bill, and asked Sir George Wakeman; ſaid he, Sir George, how are you provided? ſaid Sir George, I have been ready long ſince, but you have not been ſo punctual with me: But what have you there? ſaid Harcourt, I have a Bill of 2000 l. From whom, ſaid Sir George Wak • man? Then he named a Gentleman, but I don't know him, nor can't remember h • m. And ſaid he, I came now from Whitehall, and receiv'd it from ſuch an One, which he ſaid was by the Queen's Order, and that he had it from Her. This Bill is charged upon ſuch a Goldſmith, and named him, he dwelt ſomewhere about St. Dunſtan's Chur •• , but I can't remember his name, I'le tell you by and by why I think he dwelt there. Aſſoon as Sir Geo. had read it, 'tis well ſaid he, if it be accepted, I find more incouragement from my good Lady and Miſtriſs, than from any of you all. They had ſome little more diſcourſe, and Sir George asked of Harcourt who I was; ſaid he, 'tis a Friend that hath been long engaged in our buſineſs, and is to do the next great work to Yours. VVell ſaid Sir George, I will go and ſee if the Bill be accepted, and you ſhall hear of me to night; and accordingly he did go. I did not ſtay but a very little time after him, and therefore I Collect he could not go far to get the Bill accepted: for I did croſs Lincoln-Inn Fieids and came down a Lane by Temple-Bar, and between the Queens Head and Chancery Lane end I met with Sir George Wakeman: ſaid I, have you been with your Bill already, and is it accepted? yes ſaid he, 'tis accepted: and when is it to be paid? I am to go, ſaid he, in the Afternoon to receive it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVho ſaid ſo?

sp.speaker: mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: Sir George Wakeman.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Mr, Bedloe
sp.p: To me. And ſeeing of him return from the City-ward again, I concluded it was not far off, and ſpoke to him as I tell you. Sir George and I were not very well acquainted, but I had known him five years. and upon that Character Mr. Harcourt had given of me, I thought I might make bold with him, & when I asked him and accoſted him with that ſhort Queſtion, is your Bill accepted? he made me anſwer it was, and he was to receive it in the afternoon, and thought it not fit to diſpute any thing with me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You don't know what Goldſmith it was upon?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: It muſt be one that lives about St. Dunſians Church or Fleceſtreet. for he could not go for in that time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Where was Harcourts Chamber?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p:
I • Dukes-ſtree next the Arch. Now I asked Harcourt afterward; whether this was part of the 1500l. ſaid he, we have not adjuſted that matter yet, but he received
this only as a preſent ſupply. And he did in a ſhort time, after receive as much as made it up 5000l. But I asked whether it were for the old buſineſs, yes ſaid he, 'tis for the fame deſign, if we ſhould fail of it by other means: (and ſo was the diſcourſe to Sir George Wakeman.) If we ſhould fail of it at Windſor then this way is to be taken, and if this fail too, we will make ſure of it at New-market.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What do you know of the other Priſoners?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: mr. Corker I have ſeen with Kains and le Fevre, but never in their Company but once, where being in the great Court at Somerſet▪ houſe we walked out of the Court into the Piazza, and there we were ſpeaking of our buſineſs. Kaines was ſaying to me, You brought ſuch a letter ſuch a time for me and I have loſt it. I do not know what to do for it. Said I, do you remember the Contents of it? Yes, ſaid he I do. Said I, you ſhould take ſuch Letters in ſuch a Character as none could read but your • elf, and then burn the Letters themſelves. Said he, I hope it will not come to light, for none will meddle with my papers that can do me any hurt. I heard nothing from Mr. Corker that did relate poſitively to the murder of the King, but Corker and le Fevre were ſpeaking in general about the buſineſs, what Letters they had received from beyond Sea how to manage their affairs.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: About what matter?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: About the Plot, what Letters they had received from beyond Sea, and how forward they were in their proceedings here.

sp.speaker: Corker.
sp.p: What did we talk about?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What was it about ſtill?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: It was about raiſing the Army, and what Intereſt he had with the People, It was in general, I come not to particulars.

sp.speaker: Corker,
sp.p: Did Kaines or I, or any of us name any ſuch thing as Plot, deſign, or the like?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: We were diſcourſing of the Buſineſs in general. I don't take upon me to ſpeak to particulars.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What was it about, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: About raiſing an Army, what Intereſt he had in the people, who had been ſent into the Countrey, what they had done, and the like.

sp.speaker: Corker,
sp.p: Did you hear any word of killing, Army, or d • ſign?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: Yes, every one of thoſe w • rds were uſed. I don't take upon me to tell how the words were placed.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ward.
sp.p: What ſay you to the reſt?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: When was this diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: July was twelve moneth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ward.
sp.p: What ſay you to mr. Marſhal?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p:
Mr. Marſhal hath reaſon to know me, and I ſuppoſe will not pretend to the contrary▪ fo • he cannot but remember that I knew him when I went to the Gate-houſe. He hath corryed ſeveral Letters that have been brought from beyond Sea, and others that have been writ in England into the Countrey, and I hav • been with him in Latham's Chamber in the Savay, and Somerſet-houſe, ſo long ſince as Latham was one of the Qu • ens Monks. He hath carryed the ſame Letters that I have brought from beyond the 〈…〉 four, or more at a time to communicate to the Country gentlemen of the Catholick party, that were Aſſi • ants to us, particularly to S ••
Francis Radcliff & others I am ſure he hath carryed, and he knew what was the effect of thoſe Letters, and what were the Anſwers to them; he read them as well as any of them, for I think.
he is of the ſame Order to the beſt of my knowledg, though I never ſaw him in his habit.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What was the Import of the Letters?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: I never brought any one Letter to the Religious Fathers, and I have brought a great many, but what did import what I have now given in Evidence, and did relate to the full ſubſtance of what I ſay now.

sp.speaker: Sir Ro: Sawyer.
sp.p: Can you mention the particulars of any one Letter that he knew the Contents of?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: I do mention one which I very well remembet and that was to Sir Francis Radcliff, and I remember it though it be long ſince becauſe I w •• well acquainted with Sir Francis R • dcliffs Son, and I brought Comendations from his ſon to England.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Sawyer,
sp.p: Well Sir, what was the contents of that letter?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: It was a copy of the letter from le Cheeſe in Paris to the Monks & Jeſuits in England in anſwer to the firſt letters that • brought over to them relating to the management of the deſign.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Was it mentione in that letter what the deſign was?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: In that which I carried over to le Cheeſe, it was, that all things were in readineſs, and the time now drawing near for they did hope in • year or two, or in a little time they ſhould be in a capacity to put this in practice, and they did not queſtion but to ſubvert the oppreſſion and Tyranny the Catholick • were under in England.

sp.speaker: Sir Robert Sawyer,
sp.p: Was mr. Marſhal acquainted with the contents▪

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: He was one of them that uſe to examine the anſwers. It was written to him partly, for if he were not a member of then Order as I think he is, he was one of the club & conſult that ſaw the contents of al • letters. I have not ſeen him ſo often as I have done the others, but I believe he hath been there as often but he hath received to my remembrance twice letters to communicate into the country concerning the ſubverſion of the Government, and the introducing of Pope • y.

sp.speaker: Mr. Ward,
sp.p: What ſay you to mr. Rumly;

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: I cannot be poſitive as to my own knowledg, but what mr. Harcourt has ſaid.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you know any thing of your own knowledg by him?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe
sp.p: I have been told he hath communicated letters of this buſineſs into the country. And that he was one employed when any ſecret letters were ſent.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
So you cannot declare upon your Oath that you know that mr. Rumley kn ••
• he contents of any 〈…〉 to the Plot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: No my Lord, I do not. I have a good remembrance of faces, but I do not remember his.

sp.speaker: Sir George Wakeman,
sp.p: W •• t day was it th • t I had the diſcourſe with Harcourt, and received the Bill from him as you ſay?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: You ask me a qu • ſtion as if I were in the ſtate I was formerly in, when I might have an indulgence of or telling a lye. N I have no delight to damn my Soul, to ma • e you a Martya; but to ſatisfie you as well as I can, I ſay, it was the beginning of Auguſt. or part of the beginning, I do not ſp • ak to a day.

sp.speaker: Sir George Wakeman,
sp.p: How do you know it was a B • l • of Exchange for this money?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: You did read it aloud.

sp.speaker: Sir Go •• ge Wakeman,
sp.p: Had I any acquaintance with you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: No, But mr. Harcourt told you who I was.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo •• ge Wakeman,
sp.p: And would I upon the firſt ſight of a man diſcover to him what would endanger my life?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedlow,
sp.p: Ay, and an hundred times more, if mr▪ Harcourt, did but tell you I was his 〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: L. C. J
sp.p: What were the contents of that note?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: I • was directed to a 〈…〉 , whoſe name I tell you I cannot remember.

sp.speaker: Si Ge •• ge VVakeman,
sp.p: You are good at remembring ſome ſir-names, why can't you remember this n • me as we • l?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p:
I can remember names that do relate to any buſineſs, but only hearing this name by the by I cannot remember u, f • r I
• id not then think it of ſuch conſequence.

sp.speaker: Sir George VVakeman,
sp.p: You do not k • ow me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedlow,
sp.p: Yes I do.

sp.speaker: Sir G • orge VVakeman,
sp.p: I cal God to 〈◊〉 I never ſaw you before in my life tha • I know of. You have a very remarkable face, and if a man had once ſeen you he muſt know you again.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who ſubſcribed that Note?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p:
I don't know, 〈◊〉 was one of the Queens Gentlemen that Harcourt had if from. And whereas S ••
George VVakeman ſayes he does not know me, I did take phyſick of him at the Bath?

sp.speaker: Sir George Wakeman,
sp.p: VVhen was I at the Bath.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: It is ſome years ſince.

sp.speaker: S • r G VVakeman,
sp.p: I never was there but once, and that was a year and an half ago.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: No ſir, it is more, than that, for you were there when the Queens was there.

sp.speaker: Lord. Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: How long is it ago that you were there Sir George?

sp.speaker: Sir George VVakeman,
sp.p: It was about two years ago.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: It is three years this Samm •• .

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Then that is well enough▪ for that is ſome years ſince.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: I had acqu • intance enough with him while he was there▪

sp.speaker: Sir G. VVakeman,
sp.p: I ſay this, my Lord, if I had been acquinted with mr. Bedlow, I ſhould have known him to be a g • eat Rogue, wh • ch is But what he hath ſaid of himſelf; and then I ſhould not have thought it fit to have truſted ſuch an one wi •• ſuch a great ſecret as this.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: It may he call himſelf great 〈◊〉 for that which you would have applauded him for, and canonized him too. It may 〈◊〉 thinks he was 〈◊〉 for, going ſo far as he did; but perhaps you are of another or 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe.
sp.p: My Lord, I could not count my ſelf an honeſt •• an, that had conſe • t • d to the death of the King and Sir Edmundbury Godſ •• y.

sp.speaker: Sir G Wakeman,
sp.p: But though he gives you an account of ſuch a Bill delivered to me, yet neither he tells you the time, nor mention • the man upon whom it was drawn: Here are all the •• arks of falſhood that can poſſibl, he.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: No, he does not mention the man upon whom it was drawn, nor from whom; nor can he ſay that ever you received it, but you were to receive it.

sp.speaker: Sir G. VVakeman,
sp.p: How came he to omit that? but becauſe I ſhould have no plea for my ſelf when I came to be accuſed of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: Pray Sir George don't preſs me to ſay more than I know. I do tell you all that I can ſay of my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recerder,
sp.p: Have you any more queſtions to ask him?

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: I ask you this queſtion; Firſt, Why will you damn your ſoul to ſend me to Heaven? Lay your hand upon your heart, and in the preſence of God declare whether ever you ſaw me in your life, before you came to the Gatehouſe? Whether ever you ſaw me in any part of the world whatſoever? And whereas you ſay now that I owned that I knew you there; it was ſo far from it, that all the company that were there, will ſay that you did not know me, and declared your ſelf a ſtranger to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe▪
sp.p: No, Sir, pardon me; you did not deny but that you had ſeen my face.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: No, all the company that were there will ſay that you owned your ſelf a ſtranger to me, you told me mr. Marſhal, Be not afraid, I will do you no hurt. But mr. Bedloe, where have you ſeen me?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: At the Benedictines Convent in the Savoy. And my Lord, the firſt word that I ſaid, when I ſaw him, was, that this mans name is Marſhall, and he carried ſuch & ſuch letters into the countrey, and Sir William Waller can teſtifie the ſame.

div.stage: (VVho ſtanding upon the Bench was ſworn,)

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder,
sp.p: mr. Marſhall, you had beſt to hearken to what Sir VVilliam Waller ſays,

sp.speaker: Sir William Waller.
sp.p: My Lord, I went to the priſon to ſee mr. Maſhall, and mr. Bedloe was there with me, mr. Bedloe asked him if he did not know him, and called him by his name; he declared he had ſeen him before, but ſaid he did not know him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he call him by his Name as if he knew him?

sp.speaker: Sir William VValler.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord he did.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you, mr. Marſhal, he ſayes that you your ſelf owned that you had ſeen him before, though you were not of his acquaintance,

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: What Sir William Waller ſays, I muſt oppoſe, though I am extremely ſorry ſo to do. Sir William, you may pleaſe to remember, that you came to me after mr: Bedloe was gone.

sp.speaker: Sir William Waller.
sp.p: No, I was there with you before he came in.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: I believe thoſe of the Gatehouſe do remember that I ſpoke with mr. Bedloe in private in an interior Room; what you ſpoke was in the open Hall there. You asked me whether mr. Bedloe had not been there? I to • d you yes that was in the publick • lace; whereas mr. Bedloe talked with me only in a private Room.

sp.speaker: Sir W • lliam Waller.
sp.p: My Lord, what I have ſaid is upon my Oath, and 'tis nothing but the truth.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: And I am upon my life, therefore I am very ſorry I muſt for the truth ſake, and defence of my life contradict what you ſay. What your • worſhip and I ſpoke was in the publick Room; but what diſcourſe mr. Bedloe and I had, was in another private Room.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you, Sir William Waller, was you there when mr. Bedloe was with him.

sp.speaker: Sir William VValler,
sp.p: I was my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhere?

sp.speaker: Sir VVilliam VValler,
sp.p: In the common Room.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVhat did he ſay concerning mr. Bedloe in the common Room?

sp.speaker: Sir VVilliam VValler.
sp.p: Mr. Bedloe called him by his name and asked if he knew him? he ſaid he had ſeen his face, but did not know him.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Do you hear that mr. Marſhall?

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p:
Truly, my Lord, it goes againſt my heart to ſpeak any t •• g in oppoſition
to what Sir VVilliam VValler ſays, for I would not for all the world reflect or▪ ſay▪ any thing that ſhould glance upon Sir VVilliam VValler, as if he had taken a falſe Oa h • b • t all in the Gat • h▪ uſe Nay Mr Bedloe himſel • knows that he had diſcourſe with me in a private Room before Sir VVilliam VValler came.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Mr. Bedloe ſpeak yourſelf; was Sir William VValler there, when you came to the Gatehouſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: My Lord, I had an Order from the Council-Board to go and ſee the priſoner, there was no body that told me his name, nor that I knew, knew it; but I would not do it, I was ſo cautious, but in the hearing and company of a Juſtice of Peace, and therefore I went away before they had called him down, and I went to ſee if the Houſe of Commons were ſitting; and when I came back, Sir W. VValler was juſt coming thither, and ſo I went in with him, for I met him at the bottom of the Stairs. We came into the common Room, and there was Mr. Marſhall with the Keeper, and I was in no other Room, but the common Room. And Sir W. VValler withdrew to the end of the Room while I asked him ſome Queſtions; and pray will you pleaſe to ask Sir W. Waller whether I did not call him by his name as ſoon as I ſaw him?

sp.speaker: Sir VV. Waller.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he did: He asked him if his name was not Marſhal? and whether he did not know him? And he ſaid he had ſeen his face, but had no acquaintance with him.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: Were not you with me firſt in that Room which turns in on the right hand from the common Room?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: I do not know any ſuch Room in the Gatehouſe.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: There were your Guards, Mr. Bedloe, and there were ſeveral others in the Gate-houſe; they cannot but remember what Room I was brought into, They cannot poſſibly but remember, that when Sir William Waller came to me, he asked me whether Mr. Bedloe, had been with me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you, Gentlemen, they have done, call what Witneſſes you will, and make your defence as well as you can▪

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: my Lord, I did not think or imagine any ſuch thing would be ſpoke of; or that there would need any atteſtation for it.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Look you, they have done; we will hear what your Witneſſes will ſay, as long as you will.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: my Lord, Mr. Bedloe ſee • 'd a perfect ſtranger to me when he came to the Gate-houſe; and to encourage me, told me Mr. Marſhall (ſays he) do not fear, I will do you no hurt at all. Did not you ſend (ſaith he) to ſuch an one, to have Mr▪ Bedloe queſtioned about ſuch and ſuch things? Which I denied, and he did not ſeem by any word that he ſpoke▪ to have ſeen m • before in his life.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He told Sir W. VValler your name was Marſhall, though you went by a wrong name, the name of Marſh.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: He might eaſily know my name by thoſe that took me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But I tell you, you went by a wrong name then, Marſh.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p:
my Lord, I am called promiſ • uo • ſly Marſh and Marſhall. But Marſhall is the
• am • I own.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And that is the name he knew you by.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: I did not call my ſelf Marſh when I was taken, but told my true name.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p:
my Lord, I did not hear of any name at all, but I ſaid, This is Marſhall,
one of the Benedictine Monks▪ as ſoon as I came in:

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: mr. Bedloe ſeem'd to encourage me to hope, and bid me not fear; ſaid he, You will have an Honourable Bench, and a good Jury. And this they that were there, can teſtifie.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: Call them: call your VVitneſſes.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: But, my Lord, I did not know any thing of this. And Sir W. Waller's queſtion that he asked me was, if Mr. Bedloe was with me.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: You hear what he ſayes.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: I am infinite loth to ſay it, becauſe he ſwears it▪ and you well know, Mr. Bedloe, you talked with your Guards a while, and then turned at laſt to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: Yes, I did talk with my Guards, but Sir W. VValler was in the room as well as I.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: By what name were you committed?

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: I had Letters about me writ to me by that name; and I thought it my duty to anſwer to that name that the Letters did call me by.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: VVell, have you any witneſſes?

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: This is a ſurprize, I did not know of any ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: H • ve you any witneſſes, Sir G. VVakeman?

sp.speaker: Sir G VVakeman,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I have ſeveral.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: But mr. Bedloe, can you ſay you have ſeen me any where before you ſaw me at the Gatehouſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: VVhere?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: At the Savoy.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: And any where elſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: Yes and at other places.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: Name one other place in the whole world, and I will be contented to dye.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: I will tell you why I cannot name any other place poſitively. I did carry the Letters thither: there were the conſults about them, and there I uſed to converſe with you moſt.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: can you prove that ever you were in the Savoy in your life? and I will be hanged without any thing more to do. If you can prove it either by man, woman, or child, I will go to the Gal • ows, and will not ſay one word more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: my Lord, I have other witneſſes, but at preſent I cannot produce them: there are ſome in Kent, they are ſome of them in one Countrey, and ſome in another, I reſerve them for another time, but there is Oath made of it before the Secret Committe • s of the Lords and Commons.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: How can he imagine that this ſhould be put upon him? therefore you may well b • l • eve that • e hath never a VVitneſs preſent. It may be he hath none can prove he ever was at VV • ſtmi • ſter H • ll in his life, for who could imagine ſuch a Queſtion ſhould be put to him?

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p:
Having been there ſeveral times, I ſuppoſe he did not uſe to go alone; 'tis imp • ſſib • e, b • t if they had been with him often there, he might prove i • ; if he ſay true, ſu • e ſome ſh • uld atteſt •
〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: 'Tis likely 〈◊〉 ſhould be ſo, b • t • e hath them not h • re.

sp.speaker: Mr. J. 〈◊〉 ,
sp.p: why, do you think he can bring VVitneſſes for every Act that he did in his l •• e?

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p:
I he have them not here▪
• et him h • ve time to produce them.

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: He hath a Witneſs in Kent, would you have us keep up the Jury till he ſends for his witneſs out of Ken • ?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: There is my Landlord, at whoſe houſe I lay ſo long, can teſtifie it.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: mr. C • tt a Beltmaker in the New Exchange▪ He hath gone often with me when I have gone into the Convent, and he hath gone round about, and his maid that uſed to carry the • ortmantle, wherein I brought over the Letters from beyond Sea.

sp.speaker: L▪ C. J.
sp.p: Can you name any one body that ever ſee you in the Savoy?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: I do name one, and beſides; my Lord, I lay in the Savoy half a year at one Woodroffs.

sp.speaker: Marſhall.
sp.p: Was that the place you ſaw me in?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: No, no body came there but Monks and meſſengers.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: Was you there at the time when the Savoy was ſearched?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: No, but I gave Sir W. Waller directions to ſearch in the moſt material places of it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Recorder,
sp.p: He ſays a material thing, if he be in the right, that he did give directions to • Sir W. Waller to ſearch in the moſt material places of the Savoy. We will ask that Queſtion of Sir William whether he did or no?

sp.speaker: Sir W. Waller,
sp.p: Both Mr. Oates and Mr. Bedloe did give me directions to ſearch in the Savoy; they told me of ſuch a particular Room where Pickering lay, and where ſuch a Cloſet was, & many other things; and it was by their directions that I made the ſearch.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Look you what Sir W. Waller ſays; He ſays that both Mr. Oates and Mr. Bedloe did deſcribe ſeveral Rooms to him in the Savoy, which it was impoſſible for them to make ſuch a deſcription, if they had not been there before.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: I deſire to know when that diſcription was given?

sp.speaker: Sir W. Waller,
sp.p: Two or three days before I took Mr. Marſhall.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: Mr. Oates made ſearches there before.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But we ſpeak of Bedloe now.

sp.speaker: Marſhall
sp.p: But Mr. Bedloe might have knowledge from him and others that were there.

sp.speaker: L▪ C. J.
sp.p: Do you think he muſt needs go officiouſly to inform Bedloe of what he found upon an imagination that ſuch a Queſtion ſhould fall out hereon? And if he received no information, how then could he deſcr • b • the Rooms without he knew them?

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: May there not be ſeveral Houſes that I may give a diſcription of, upon the hearſay of others, though I were never in them my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Lord Ch. Juſt.
sp.p: No, I know not very w • ll how; and there is no reaſon you ſhould imagine he received information from Oates.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: my Lord, there is reaſon enough, becauſe both do c • mb • ne in the ſame accuſation.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: My Lord, I gave Sir W. Waller directions to ſearch in ſuch a place, under ſuch a Bench in Pickerings Apa • tment, where he found the Gun that was to kill the King.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well, call your witneſſes, Sir George.

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman,
sp.p: Call Mr. Chapman.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p:
But before they begin, Sir Robe •• Sawyer, we muſt do all the right to every one we can; I do not find by the ſtricteſt obſervation that I have made, that Mr. Bedloe, who is the ſecond witneſs, does ſay any great thing, any material thing againſt any one of them; but as for Rumley, he ſays nothing at all. He ſays in effect, againſt Sir George Wakeman, no more than this, That he ſaw Harcourt give him a Note for
2000l. which he ſaid was from the Queen; upon which Sir George ſaid he was more beholden to his good Lady and Miſtreſs, than to any of them all. The Note he does not know who drew it, nor upon whom it was drawn; nor does he ſay what it was for, more than Harcourt told him, which was in doubtful words, That it was about the old buſineſs; but Harcourt did not tell him this in the preſence of Sir George Wakeman, but he ſpoke to Harcourt about it. It is no more, than Sir George Wakeman received from Harcourt the Bill of Exchange, he does not know upon whom, nor for what.

sp.speaker: Sir R • b. S • wyer,
sp.p: My Lord, he ſays more, with ſubmiſſion; for he ſays this further, That there was a diſcourſe about the buſineſs; and he did tell you, That Sir George Wakeman ſhould complain that they had not done well with him, and asked why he was drill'd on; but when the Note • was produced, he ſaid, My matters are already prepared, but you are not ſo ready to perform your promiſes. Then ſaid Harcourt, If you are ready for us, we are ready for you; and told him, If he did not do it, they would do it at New-market.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What is all this? Pray Mr. Bedloe ſtand up again, We are now in the caſe of mens lives, and pray have a care that you ſay no more than what is true upon any man whatever. I would be loth to keep out Popery by that way they would bring it in, that is by Blood or Violence. I would have all things go very fair. Pray what, upon y • ur Oath, was the firſt part of Sir George Wakemans diſcourſe with Harcourt when they met?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: North, Relate again your whole knowledge concerning Sir George Wakeman, and the Bill of Exchange, and the diſcourſe after it, becauſe we are now upon the conſidera • ion of it, what effect it will have upon him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: My Lord, I was with Harcourt in the Chamber, and Sir George Wakeman came in, and walked a turn or two about the Room, and ſeemed to be diſcontented. How do you, Sir George, ſaid Harcourt? Says Sir George, For what am I drill'd on thus in a concern of this importance? What is the matter with you, Sir George, ſaid Harcourt? Why, is this a buſineſs to be ſlighted, ſaid Sir George, as I am? for I have no performance of your promiſes. Why, ſaid Harcourt, what would you have? We are ready for you. Then ſaid he, I am ready for you. And then Harcourt ſpoke merrily to him, Why are you ſo angry, Sir George? And upon that he goes to his Cabinet and ſearching among his Bags, he found a little Note among them, and gave it to Sir George; ſaith he, There is a Bill for you: I have been to day at W • itehall, and received it by the Queens Order, from ſuch a Gentleman [whoſe name I cannot now remember]; and 'tis upon ſuch a man for 2000l. [But I cannot remember the Goldſmiths name neither] Well, ſaid Sir George, 'tis well ſome body gives me encouragement; I have more encouragement from my good Lady and Miſtreſs, than from any of you. Nay, ſaid Harcourt, for encouragement, that you ſhall not want; for the reſt ſhall be paid in due time.

sp.speaker: Sir George Wakeman,
sp.p: If the Queen had given me 2000l. for the ſervice I had done her, was that any ha • m? I have deſerved it, I am ſure, for nine years ſervice.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer▪
sp.p: What other diſcourſe had they then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: Said Harcourt, But Sir George, this muſt be well followed, and cloſely obſerved, becauſe ſo much depends upon it; For if we ſhould miſs to kill him at Windſor, or you miſs in your way, we will do it at New-market.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Who ſaid ſo?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: Harcourt,

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did Harcourt ſay before Sir Georges face, If we miſs killing him at Windſor, and you miſs your way, we will do it at New-market.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: Yes, he did ſay, If we miſs killing him at Windſor, and you miſs in your way (which we hope you will not) we will do it at New-market.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: He ſays now quite another thing than he ſaid before▪

sp.speaker: L. C. J. North, Mr. Recorder, Sir R. Sawyer,
sp.p: No, He ſaid the ſame before.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What Anſwer made Sir George Wakeman?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: Sir George Wakeman ſaid, If I find you ready, I will be ready in all things.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was the word ſpoke of POYSONING?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: I have ſpoken that already. If we miſs at Windſor, and you miſs in your way; I do not remember whether the word Poyſon was uſed; but I knew by what Mr. Harcourt▪ and others had told me, that Poyſon was meant by it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Was all this one intire diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord. Then Sir George ſaid privately to his fellow-priſoners, There is my Buſineſs done.

sp.speaker: Sir Rob. Sawyer,
sp.p: Here is a poſitive proof of the Receipt of money, which coupled with what Oats ſays, and the diſcourſe that Mr. Bedloe tells you of, makes it out what it was for. This was paid in part, was it not, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: The Anſwer that Mr. Harcourt gave to Sir George, was, that he ſhould have the reſt in due time.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But what ſay you to Marſhall, but that he carried Letters?

sp.speaker: Sir George Wakeman,
sp.p: Was there no body preſent but you?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: There was only Harcourt, you and I.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But what ſay you to Corker?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: Corker hath been in the Company with Le Faire, talking of News, what encouragement they had by letters from beyond ſea, as thoſe they had from France; ſuch and ſuch letters ſpeak that they are in readineſs of money, men and arms; and if we are ready here, they are ready for us. This was uſually the diſcourſe and all upon the ſame deſign. Now when we talked of this buſineſs, we did not ſay the word PLOT, but we all know what was intended by it, that is the Plot.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And what ſaid Corker?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: He ſaid it was well, He did know what readineſs ſuch and ſuch perſons were in when the Deſign was likely to take effect. I know not their Names; we were talking of ſeveral perſons ſeveral times, ſome in England, and ſome beyoud ſea.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: What can you ſay to Marſhal?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: I do ſay, that he hath been to conſult of the return of letters which were the Anſwers to thoſe I brought from beyond ſea.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Did he know the Contents of thoſe Letters?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he hath been in Conſultation what Anſwer to make again.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: And was all this about the Plot?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: Yes, for the ſubverting the Proteſtant Religion, and bringing in Popery, and raiſing of an Army.

sp.speaker: Marſhall,
sp.p: Can you prove I knew any of thoſe Gentlemen the Letters were carried to

sp.speaker: Mr. Bedloe,
sp.p: I name one, that was to Sir Francis Radcliff.

sp.speaker: Marſh▪
sp.p: How does he know that I know Sir Francis Radcliff?

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Well Sir George, will you call your Witneſſes?

sp.speaker: Sir George Wakeman,
sp.p: Call, Mr. Chapman, (which was done.) My Lord there was a Letter or Note of Directions from me to mr. Aſhby, and 'tis affirmed by maſter Oates, that in that letter I ſhould let maſter Aſhby know I did approve well of the Propoſals that were made to me to poyſon the King, and that the Queen would aſſiſt me in it, and that in the ſame letter there were directions given what he ſhould take, and how many ſtrokes of the Pump he ſhould make uſe of, and ſeveral other things fit for a Phyſician to direct his Patient in. Now, my Lord, I will prove by▪ this Gentleman maſter Chapman • , who is Mayor of Bath, that he received this very Note from maſter Aſhby, that he read it from the beginning to the end of it; that there was no word in it, or mention of the King or Queen in the whole letter, unleſs it be of the King or Queens Bath. And, my Lord, I think he hath a piece of this letter ſtill, that part that was the Phyſical part he tore off, and kept himſelf: Now 'tis none of my hand, I never writ a letter to Aſhby upon any occaſion whatſoever; and I will tell your Lordſhip how it came to paſs, I did not write that letter, I hope by a Providence, for I never but uſed to write my Phyſical Directions with my own hand. It happened that I came home late, and I was very ill; Aſhby ſent to me for his Note, becauſe he was to go out of Town the next morning; being weary and indiſpoſed, I laid me down on the Couch, and ſent for my man, who is an Apothecary now, and is the better able to write ſuch a letter; I dictated the letter to him, all my Family, and all that were by, can teſtifie the ſame; he knows very well my hand and hath part of it to produce; for when the Queen was there, I made uſe of him for my Apothecary, and thoſe Phyſical directions I ſent down for the Bath, I ſent always to him. He is a very good witneſs as to my hand.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But you may ſpeak of one Letter, and mr. Oates of another.

sp.speaker: Sir G. Wakeman.
sp.p: Why▪ did I write two letters of directions? what need that? he ſays he ſaw a letter with my name ſubſcribed to it.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: Yes, it was ſo, and that you ſhould be aſſiſted by the Queen to poyſon the King; and being asked how he did know that was your hand? he ſaid, I did not ſee him write, but I ſaw him in the poſture of writing; and when he went away, there was left on the Table, and the Ink as not dry, a Phyſical Bill, which was the ſame hand with that the letter was.

sp.speaker: Sir George Wakeman.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord, but he does not call that a letter but it was a Phyſical Bill, and not a letter; ſo that there was but one letter.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But there was a note of Phyſical directions in the letter.

sp.speaker: Dr. Oat • s,
sp.p:
That letter was at leaſt half a ſheet of a ſide, cloſe written, wherein, were thoſe paſſages that I mentioned; but I cannot give an account of all contained in it, but this my Lord I remember, that he ſhould take a pint of Milk in the morning, and a pint of milk in the evening, and ſhould have ſo many ſtrokes at the Bath; but this was ſeveral days before Aſhby went to the Bath, I believe at leaſt ten, Preſently after, he came to Town. And I ſay, that this letter that the Court asks me how I prove i •
to be his hand, I prove it thus: I ſaw him write a Bill to an Apothecary for mr. Aſhby to take ſomething when he was in Town.

sp.speaker: L. C. J.
sp.p: But was that buſineſs of being aſſiſted to kill the King in the ſame letter tha the Phyſical Directions were in?

sp.speaker: Dr. Oates,
